The lore itself is so filled with gaps that even the jokes in the video may 
very well be true because the lore doesn't contradict anything said in this 
video. That's the genius of the cartoon. The game doesn't even tell you 
this lore in a remotely linear way. You need to piece meal it together and 
even then most people don't get as complete a picture as to what happens in 
dark souls as what you get in this video.

Here is the story.

- Immortal stone dragons ruled the world since time immemorial and wanted 
to keep it craggy and ashy which suited them best. The exception to this 
was Seath, the scaleless... who was not immortal but was desperately trying 
to figure out how and why - soon realizing it was the scales themselves. He 
needed to research this... but the only way to do it was to kill his own 
kind....

- Four Lord Souls were discovered by Gwyn, Nito, Izalith, and the Furtive 
Pygmy... and with the help of Seath the Betrayer they put an end to the 
Dragon's domination of the world and started the age of fire - an age of 
new gods who's powers kept the world in line thanks to the burning of 
something called the first flame. Gwyn, the new god king, named Seath a 
duke and presented him piece of a Lord Soul in honor.

- Keep in mind that these are not the only gods. Their children were all 
dieties (including an unnamed wargod, gwyndolyn, gwynevere, quelaag, 
quelaana, and quelaan (notice the patern)  as well as several others of 
unknown origin like Velka, Fina, and Flann,

- The age of fire was found to be temporary since the first flame was 
literally going out so Izalith attempted to recreate the first flame with 
her own lord soul but instead became a chaotic demon hellspawning.... 
thing. The city of Izalith in ruin becoming an ever spawning pool of demons.

- Seath continued his obsession with his research as well as 
[implied]sexing up humans/ giants, leading to many mutated women folk, a 
cult-like group of followers, and possibly fathering the demi-god 
crossbreed priscilla, who was banished for her unique ability to hunt other 
gods.

- Realizing that their powers were only temporary there were grumblings in 
the god's sanctuary and they soon abandoned it. They tried to found a new 
city with lords and humans, the humans getting a pieces of the Lord Soul 
but the city fell to ruin as the citizens were tempted by the abyss. It was 
decided to have everyone present killed by flood to prevent what happened 
in the past - as the abyss has welled up in these lands before in a town 
called Oolacile.

- Gwyn, in an attempt to keep his powers along with the other gods a while 
longer, cast himself into the first flame using himself as kindling, for 
only the most powerful souls can keep it lit.

- With the abyss ever creeping up on Lordran, the land of the gods, demons 
escaping from the lost city of Izalith, the fading powers of the gods, and 
now a new plague, the curse of the undying spreading across world various 
knights of various kingdoms around the world scrambled to solve the problem 
as the gods abandoned mortal concerns. The cursed undead too seem to be 
drawn to this place, though everyone but the player seems to know why.

- Gwyndolyn, Kaathe, and Frampt begin corralling whatever undead are 
willing to take up their trials to whatever ends, eventually leading them 
to the first flame. People argue which ending is canon - Linking the flames 
and keeping the age of fire going a little longer or becoming the Dark 
Lord, ending the age of the gods, the age of fire and ushering in the age 
of man, the age of dark..... but according to Dark Souls 2 this their both 
canon as both seemed to have happened repeatedly over time (I won't spoil 
any lore for DS2  here other than this).

At least this is what the fans understand the story to be years after the 
release.

The reality is that most of the story is told like this.

Someone did something. We don't know how or why.
Something else happened. We don't know when how or why.
Someone else did something. We don't know when how or why.
Curses. Abyss. Flames. THINGS.
Names of people and places. No context.
You were chosen to do something. You don't know when where what or why.
You beat the game. You don't know what you did or why.

Dark Souls 2 doesn't really answer any questions left in Dark Souls... and 
as of right now it's so new that the community doesn't have a grasp of the 
story yet. Yes, those of us who've beat DS 1 and 2 at this point have 
absolutely no idea what the story of DS2, what you accomplish, and why.

comments.text:
+Professor Stabs Most fans of the series are quite disappointed with Dark 
Souls II. It wasn't done by the same people, and it's quite noticeable the 
new makers were total amateurs. It's objectively just mediocre, whereas the 
first two Souls games could be called masterpieces that *will* be 
remembered for ages among games like Super Mario Bros.

And you being a butthurt fanboy of the game for some odd reason won't 
change the fact that it basically has no lore. It just has questions it 
poses, but doesn't answer. They intentionally made it as vague as possible 
so that fans would be busy speculating about it. We will however never get 
any more real answers, which was actually present in previous Souls games. 
They didn't really require baseless speculation, as those games had the 
answers within the game. The new designers just weren't anywhere near as 
imaginative as Miyazaki and co.

+kilian phillips None of these things will *EVER* be known because the 
answers are not in the game. Because the lore is shallow as fuck.

Unlike DeS and DaS1 which had subtle answers in game to the questions set 
by the lore, this one doesn't.

It's just bad design made by inexperienced designers. The game isn't made 
by the same people, and it shows.

In other words, what you are saying is just what I already said. Everything 
that can be known of the lore is already known. The makers of DaS2 are lazy 
and purposefully made the lore stupidly vague and didn't put in any 
answers. It's just ambiguous for the sake of being ambiguous. Not actually 
deep like in previous Souls games, just pretends to be.
comments.author: Kurt Rustle

comments.text:
+Kurt Rustle Who is the emerald Harold really? What is her motive? 
Why does the ancient dragon have a giants soul when you can find the 
dragons soul in the dragons memory. Why do you access the giants memory 
from the spider boss? Why  is it there? Why is there a Millfanito in the 
castle and why is she imprisoned? Why does our hero go along with all this? 
What is the player characters motivation, what is their objective in this 
world? Why do all the lord souls exist independently again in these bosses, 
when the hero consumed them from dark souls 1 and relinked the fire to 
enter the kiln of the first flame. There are tons of questions yet 
unanswered. The plot is not deep no, but none of the souls games have a 
deep plot the issue with dark souls 2 is that so much of it makes no sense 
as of yet. The other two souls games were more internally consistent on 
item descriptions item locations and motivations. Dark souls 2 we are given 
very little explanation, no payoffs, changing objectives, strange item 
placements among other issues. 

Right now all lore videos on the subject are still trying to connect dots 
in differing ways to explaining everything. As of yet I dont think any of 
the explanations are very satisfactory. Hopefully a more cohesive narrative 
is formed but im doubtful i think the game is just not the same without 
Miyazaki at the helm. Here is hoping he has been in charge of project beat.

top_comment.text:
It's weird, the game has some conflicting descriptions on the Black 
Knights. The description for the Knights themselves says they accompanied 
Gwyn down to the Kiln of the First Flame and were burnt black when he tried 
to light it. The description of their weapons, however, say that they were 
all used to fight chaos demons, and the description of the shield even goes 
far enough to say that "Long ago, the black knights faced the chaos demons, 
and were charred black...". Could be a translation error, but it's still a 
weird discrepancy.﻿
top_comment.author: CerberusKnox

comments.text:
I assume some where charred in the battle in the intro, and some charred at 
the kiln.
comments.author: xThunderxWolfx

comments.text:
I kind of wondered about that too but I'm thinking it's this:

Half the Knights went with Gwyn when he tried to light the First flame. The 
other half stayed at Anor Londo (must've been a much smaller army than the 
one in the intro then). When they went to the First Flame there were 
already demons there (which may explain why you see the passive phantoms of 
marching Knights as you enter the Kiln) so Gwyn split his forces. Half went 
with him, and half fought off the demons, but all of them were consumed 
when he lit the flame, no matter where they were.

Also, maybe the chaos demons caused the flame to malfunction somehow, 
incinerating everyone nearby. After all, when the Chosen Undead lights it, 
it doesn't seem to have any negative effects.
comments.author: RaxuRangerking

comments.text:
In theory, there were 3 different groups of elite knights. The honor guard 
of Gwyn who were charred at the kiln, the guards of Anor Londo and the 
vanguard who fought the chaos demons. Point being, they were split up and 
the black knights had various ways in which they were charred.

comments.text:
If you do buy em, a few tips from someone who recently bought Dark Souls 2; 
1) Be VERY careful. DO NOT rush at enemies, because you WILL die if you do. 
2) Analyze your enemies attacks. Take your time with them. Learn them. 
It'll make killing them ALOT easier. 3) Get a friend. Trust me, you'll need 
one. 3) Do NOT underestimate any enemy. As small and fragile as it may 
seem, if you are careless, it can and will kill you. (Anything, and I'm not 
exaggerating here, ANYTHING can kill you.) 5) Never let yourself get 
overwhelmed. Don't fight more than 1 enemy at a time. If you see more than 
2 enemies rushing at you, RUN, because they will kill you in a matter of 
seconds. And here comes the most important; 6) BE PATIENT. You will die. 
ALOT. And I mean, ALOT. Don't get mad. Use death as your teacher. If you 
die, analyze why you died. Maybe you dodged instead of blocked, or vice 
versa. Learn from your mistakes. Oh and time your attacks very carefully. 
Don't just attack like crazy. Wait for an opening. And one more 7) Never 
let your stamina drain. You're defenseless without it.
PRAISE THE SUN!

If you played DS1 it's normal to find DS2 easier since you're already 
familiar with the mechanics, and the series is meant to be challenging, not 
difficult, so you feel rewarded for your efforts. DS2 rewards veteran DS1 
players who made the effort of mastering the gameplay of the previous 
installment. The DLC levels on the other hand amp up the difficulty and 
offer a challenging experience even for people who know the mechanics 
pretty darn well, so be sure to enjoy that. If you didn't get the DLCs, 
wait for the upgraded version to be out on PC as to not waste your money.

artorias of the abyss expansion.

comments.text:
+LunarD3A7H
Actually the ending is like Schrödingers cat. Both endings happend and 
didn't happen at the same time, because due to the curse the cycle repeats 
itself unlimited times.
So there are technically unlimited choosen undead(that is even supported by 
the multiplayer, wich shows that there are alternated timelines in 
different worlds with different choosen undead.) and so there are unlimited 
possibilities wich of both endings where choosen.
Even if you choose one ending both endings still never happened, because 
simply a new cycle starts, but you have choosen an ending and this ending 
happened but only in this cycle and maybe you choose the other ending in 
the next cycle. So from your view both endings happend and yet you have to 
start new again and no ending happend.(I guess it start to sound confusing 
right now :P)
In DS2 on the other hand exists just one ending, because we know about the 
cycle and know that no matter what we do it will still repeat itself(Or how 
the game handles it: NG+ to NG+unlimited).

There is by the way an interesting theory about King Vendrick, wich says 
that he is a choosen undead himself. But instead of fulfilling his duty and 
linking the fire he instead tries to do nothing in hope to break the cycle.

comments.text:
+Obtenebrations I like how you put the Seath and Gwynevere ship together, 
but I ship Seath and The Fair Lady. Not only because of the white colour, 
but also because of the creatures present in the Painted World, and things 
present in Seath's archive. First thing, the Fair Lady is a firekeeper, in 
Seath's archives you find a firekeeper soul and the maiden set. The dingy 
set found on the firelink firekeeper is actually a worn maiden set. Yet 
another firekeeper in Seath's archives. So we can assume Seath likes 
experimenting with firekeepers.

In the painted world, we find hollows infected with infections similar to 
that of the egg carriers, we also find an egg vermifuge. The hollows in the 
painted world all use pyromancy, which the daughters or chaos specialise 
in. It is also worth noting that the NPC who invades you in the painted 
world - Jeramiah, uses chaos pyromacy. A Type of Pyromancy originating ONLY 
at the Witch of Izaleth, and her 7 daughters. Which means Jeramiah must 
have learnt it from them. You can also find Jeramiah's corpse in Pricilla's 
arena after you defeat him, which shows he had direct contact with 
Pricilla. Perhaps he was sent there to protect her by The Fair Lady, 
Pricilla's theoretical mother. 

As for her having access to the painting, I don't think she voluntairily 
entered. Everything put in the painting was put there because it was feared 
by the gods. The god's feared pricilla's ability to weild that power of 
lifehunt. I also belive your access to the painted world was permitted by 
Velka (the crow dropped the doll in your cell), since the crow is the one 
who transports you to and from the northern undead asylum. Velka permitted 
your entry in an attempt to open the painting and let her minions free.

I never realised that Havel was actually trapped in that tower, thansk for 
drawing my attention to that. I too agree that Seath is responsible for 
trapping him there.

I don't know which theory to support. I feel like there is substantial 
evidence for both.
